questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: NSAIDs act by  inhibiting the phospholipases.

questions.solution:
Cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) is primarily a housekeeping enzyme.

NSAIDs act by inhibiting both COX-1 and COX-2.

  • COX-1 is constitutively expressed in most cells. It performs housekeeping functions like gastrointestinal cytoprotection, fluid and electrolyte balance in the kidney.
  • COX-2 is normally present in insignificant amounts in most of the cells. It is induced by cytokines, growth factors and other stimuli during inflammation.

Phospholipase-A2 is the initial enzyme that acts on the membrane phospholipids to generate arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid produces prostaglandins by the action of the cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX).

questions.text: A patient with a history of myocardial infarction asks you why he is being prescribed aspirin. You tell him it prevents the formation of clots which reduces the risk of MI. Formation of which of the following eicosanoids is blocked by aspirin for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Thromboxane A2 is a pro-aggregatory eicosanoid whose formation requires the activity of COX enzyme. Aspirin blocks this step, thus reducing the chances of clot formation.

Thromboxane A2 is an inducer of platelet aggregation and amplifies the signal of more potent platelet agonists, such as thrombin and ADP.

Related Pearl: Prostaglandins effect on platelet action

Anti-aggregatory prostaglandins:

  • PGI2
  • PGD2

Pro-aggregatory prostaglandins:

  • Thromboxane A2
  • PGH2
  • PGG2

Variable effects are seen with PGE2

questions.text: Which of the following helps in maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) maintains the patency of ductus arteriosus (PDA). This is used in term neonates with underlying cyanotic congenital heart disease awaiting surgical intervention as they have duct-dependant circulation.

Indomethacin and Ibuprofen are the NSAID indicated for closing the ductus arteriosus in premature infants and neonates.

questions.text: A patient of CREST syndrome has developed pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following drugs will you not prescribe to treat this?
questions.solution:
Rioprostil is a PGE1 analog and is not indicated in the treatment of pulmonary hypertension.

Long term therapy with PGI2 analogs can delay or preclude the need for lung or heart-lung transplantation. PGI2 analogs used for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension are:

  • Epoprostenol (IV)
  • Iloprost (IV)
  • Treprostinil (IV or SC)

PGI2 (Epoprostenol) can also be used to prevent platelet aggregation and damage during haemodialysis or cardiopulmonary bypass. It also improves the harvest of platelets for transfusion.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has presented to the OPD with a complaint of erectile dysfunction not responding to oral medication. The issue is determined to be of vascular origin. Which prostaglandin preparation can be given as a local injection to treat this?
questions.solution:
Alprostadil (PGE1) is given as an intracavernosal injection or urethral suppository for erectile dysfunction.

It is considered as a second-line therapy. Its use has been largely replaced by phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors like sildenafil and tadalafil which are the drugs of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about aspirin?

choices.text: It is an irreversible inhibitor of the cyclooxygenase enzyme.
Its clearance is independent of plasma concentration at low dose.
Alkalinization of urine increases its rate of excretion.
Its antiplatelet effect at low dose is related to presystemic COX inhibition.

questions.solution:
Aspirin clearance is dependent on plasma concentration at a lower dose.

Aspirin shows saturation kinetics. This means that at lower plasma concentrations it has first-order kinetics where the rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration but at higher plasma concentrations it has zero-order kinetics where the rate of elimination is independent of its plasma concentration.

Around 80-90% of aspirin (salicylates) are bound to plasma proteins, especially albumin.

Low dose aspirin acetylates the COX enzyme of platelets in the portal circulation (pre-systemic) and deactivates it which is responsible for antiplatelet action.

Aspirin and salicylates are acidic in nature. Alkalinization of the urine increases the rate of excretion of aspirin, as ionised form of aspirin increases which is not reabsorbed from the tubular fluid in kidney. 

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A 12-year-old child developed fever during an epidemic of influenza. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this child?
questions.solution:
Aspirin is contraindicated in this child due to the risk of development of Reye syndrome.

Children and young adults less than 20 years of age with viral fever have a risk of developing Reye's syndrome on administration of aspirin or other salicylates.

Features of Reye syndrome include:

  • Acute onset of encephalopathy
  • Liver dysfunction
  • Fatty infiltration of the liver 

Option A - Acetaminophen is considered the antipyretic of choice in children with viral infections.

Options C and D - Oseltamivir and baloxavir are antiviral drugs used in influenza.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pilot with low back pain requires a painkiller that is effective at once-daily dosing. You decide to prescribe the NSAID with the longest plasma half-life. Which drug will you choose?
questions.solution:
Piroxicam is chosen as it has the longest plasma half-life among NSAIDs.

Piroxicam is absorbed completely and undergoes enterohepatic circulation. Due to the long half-life, once-daily administration of the drug is sufficient for the therapeutic response.

questions.text: A patient with a history of gastritis complains of joint pain. You diagnose it to be a case of osteoarthritis and prescribe celecoxib. Which of the following statements is true regarding this drug?

choices.text: It is more likely to cause gastric ulcers compared to ibuprofen
It is not associated with cardiotoxicity

questions.solution:
Celecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor. As COX-2 enzyme is constitutively active within the kidney, recommended doses of selective COX-2 inhibitors cause renal toxicities similar to those associated with traditional NSAIDs.

Option B - It is less likely to cause gastric ulcers.  Celecoxib has analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory effects similar to those of non-selective NSAIDs but with better gastrointestinal tolerability.

Option C - It inhibits COX-2-mediated prostacyclin synthesis in the vascular endothelium. As a result, use of celecoxib is associated with increased cardiovascular risk.

Option D - Celecoxib at usual doses does not inhibit platelet aggregation. This is because platelet aggregation is mediated by thromboxane produced by the COX-1.

These points are also true for other selective COX-2 inhibitors.

Related Pearl: Some Important Points about Selective COX-2 Inhibitors

They are also known as coxibs. They are different from non-selective COX inhibitors as follows:

  • Fewer GI side effects as COX-1 is not inhibited
  • No antiplatelet action as thromboxane A2 production is unaffected.

Adverse effects and contraindications:

  • Myocardial infarction
  • Stroke
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hypertension
  • Renal impairment.

Order of COX-2 selectivity

  • Lumiracoxib > etoricoxib > rofecoxib > valdecoxib > celecoxib.
  • Lumiracoxib - most selective
  • Celecoxib - least selective

The only coxib which can be given parenterally is Parecoxib.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has the least COX-2 selectivity?
questions.solution:
Celecoxib has the least COX-2 selectivity among the following.

Some selective COX-2 inhibitors are withdrawn or have restricted use because of an increase in the risk of cardiovascular events like myocardial infarction, serious skin reactions (valdecoxib), fatal hepatic failure (lumiracoxib).

Nowadays, dual inhibitors inhibiting 5-LOX and COX like licofelone and tepoxalin are also used for their anti-inflammatory property.

questions.text: Your senior asks you to administer a selective COX-2 inhibitor intravenously to a patient for post-op analgesia. Which of the following will you choose?
questions.solution:
Parecoxib is chosen as it is the only injectable COX-2 selective drug among the given options.

It is a water-soluble prodrug of valdecoxib. It is effective in the perioperative period when oral medications are not indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about acetaminophen?

choices.text: It has significant analgesic, antiinflammatory and antipyretic action.
It does not antagonize effects of uricosuric drugs.

questions.solution:
Acetaminophen does not antagonize effects of uricosuric agents. It may be used concomitantly with probenecid in the treatment of gout as it does not have any effect on uric acid levels.

Option A - Acetaminophen has analgesic and antipyretic action equivalent to aspirin but lacks a significant anti-inflammatory effect.

Option B - Acetaminophen toxicity causes centrilobular necrosis.

Option D - It is a weak inhibitor of both COX-1 and COX-2 and has minimal or no effect on platelet activity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient of major depression presented to the ER after having consumed 20 tablets of acetaminophen (500 mg each) 1 hour ago in a self-harm attempt. She does not have any symptoms at the moment. Which of the following should you administer to her?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given clinical scenario has ingested a potentially toxic dose of acetaminophen. N-acetylcysteine is considered as a definitive antidote for acetaminophen poisoning to prevent hepatic injury.

N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) is a toxic metabolite of acetaminophen which causes hepatotoxicity. In adults, hepatotoxicity may occur after ingestion of a single dose of 10–15 g (150–250 mg/kg) of acetaminophen; doses of 20–25 g or more are potentially fatal.

In acetaminophen poisoning, due to increased NAPQI, there is utilization of glutathione (GSH). This in turn leads to depletion of GSH leading to oxidative cellular damage of the hepatocytes. N-acetylcysteine replenishes GSH stores and also conjugates with NAPQI and prevents oxidative damage to the cell. It also protects against extrahepatic injury due to its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.

Option A: Flumazenil is an antidote for benzodiazepine toxicity.

Option C: Methylene blue is used in methemoglobinemia.

Option D: Symptoms may take upto 2 days to develop in a case of acetaminophen poisoning by which time the hepatic damage may become irreversible. Thus, early treatment is initiated in all suspected cases.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not considered a hit and run drug?
questions.solution:
Piroxicam is a reversible inhibitor of cyclooxygenase enzyme and cannot be considered as a hit and run drug.

Hit and run drugs are a group of drugs whose half-life is short, but cause irreversible inhibition of a particular enzyme. So, the effect of the drug is present even after the drug is cleared from the system. Examples include: 

  • MAO inhibitors ( e.g.: Phenelzine)
  • PPI (e.g.: omeprazole)
  • Guanethidine
  • Reserpine
  • Aspirin

questions.text: Which of the following patients should be prescribed NSAIDs for pain relief?

choices.text: A hypertensive patient on chlorthalidone having osteoarthritis
Patient complaining of low back pain who is a known case of CKD

questions.solution:
NSAIDs can be used in the treatment of primary dysmenorrhea. Prostaglandin release from endometrium causes cramps and other symptoms. NSAIDs inhibit the synthesis of prostaglandin and cause symptomatic relief.

Option A: NSAIDs interfere with the antihypertensive effect of diuretics. The exact mechanism is not yet known. So it should be avoided in such cases.

Option C: NSAIDs are generally avoided in renal diseases as inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis worsens renal function.

Option D: NSAIDs generally lack efficacy in cases of neuropathic pain like diabetic neuropathy.

questions.text: A patient of chronic low back pain has presented to your OPD with deranged LFT reports. He tells you he has been on long term treatment with a painkiller for his condition. Which NSAID has he most likely been taking?
questions.solution:
Diclofenac is the NSAID that has the highest risk of hepatotoxicity within the therapeutic dose.

Liver injury occurs in acetaminophen overdose but it is extremely rare in therapeutic dose. NSAIDs are not recommended in advanced hepatic and renal failure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male on multiple drugs presents with a round macule on his right leg for the last 7 days. The patient gives a history of similar episodes in the past which resolved spontaneously. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This is a case of fixed drug eruption and the most likely cause is ibuprofen.

Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by sharply demarcated dull red to brown lesions. They occur in lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and cause a burning sensation. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug.

Some of the drugs commonly known to cause fixed drug eruptions are Sulphonamides, NSAIDs, Analgesics, and Hypnotics.

Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology. Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.

Phenytoin and carbamazepine can lead to Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) and drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome).
